People's Classed and Gendered Aspirations</titl>         <IDNo agency="UKDA">851484</IDNo>         <IDNo agency="datacite">10.5255/UKDA-SN-851484</IDNo>       </titlStmt>       <rspStmt> <topcClas>Education</topcClas>         <topcClas>Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>Transcript data; school summaries; particiapnt overview; research tools.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2012-09-17T00:00:00Z">17 September 2012</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2014-07-16T00:00:00Z">16 July 2014</collDate>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogCover>London; Manchester and the Rural South West</geogCover>         <anlyUnit>groups</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit>individuals</anlyUnit>         <dataKind>Alpha-numeric</dataKind>         <dataKind>Textual</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <collMode>We used a multi-stage, mixed-method approach.  We combined textual analysis of celebrity representations with empirical data from face-to-face group and individual interviews, and online forums to give young people a role in steering the research.  Using group interviews and online forums allowed us to examine participants\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd' collective negotiation of meanings, alongside biographical narratives from one-to-one interviews, providing a rich, unique body of data.    The research took place in six 11-19 co-educational comprehensive schools.  We accessed 144 participants, 24 per school.  Half the participants were from Year 10 (aged 14-15) and half from Year 12 (aged 16-17).  We conducted  four group interviews per school with six participants in each lasting approximately 45 minutes.  In group interviews we examined the shared negotiation of meanings around aspiration and celerity. We used an open, semi-structured approach to ensure that the research is led by young people\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds meanings and practices, however we will use celebrity representations as prompts to encourage discussion on celebrity, achievable and desirable educational and career pathways, and connections between them.   We also conducted a further 48 individual interviews (8 per school), lasting approximately 45 minutes to examine more closely their aspirations, engagement with celebrity, class and gender positions, and links between these.   </collMode>         <sources />       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <contact><a href="mailto:heathermendick@yahoo.co.uk">Heather Mendick, Brunel University</a></contact>         <contact><a href="mailto:k.allen@mmu.ac.uk">Allen Kim, Manchester Metropolitan University</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat />   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
